To support the Jette Parker Young Artist Program (at Queensland Ballet Company), a year-long apprenticeship programme offering young talented dancers a career pathway and building the next generation of internationally sought-after dancers. Queensland Ballet Company is a dance company in Queensland (Australia) connecting people and dance through performance, training, education and community engagement activities.

Organisation: RADIX Fondation Suisse pour la promotion de la santeÌ
Purpose: To update the website feel-ok.ch, which provides health advice to adolescents in the German-speaking part of Switzerland, and to develop a version suitable for smartphones and tablets. RADIX is a national competence centre for the promotion, development and implementation of public health measures and plays an intermediary role between the Confederation, cantons and municipalities.

Organisation: RADIX Fondation Suisse pour la promotion de la santé
Purpose: To support Radix to implement a national project which encourages adolescents to acquire positive life skills and to achieve healthy dating relationships. RADIX is a Swiss national centre for the development and implementation of public health measures.
Sub Programme: Engaging men and boys in ending sexual abuse

Purpose: To assist Rahi, based in India, to provide leadership on issues of child sexual abuse and incest. When adult survivors of incest have access to opportunities for self-healing and recovery, they often create similar opportunities for other survivors. This grant will enable Rahi to consolidate and expand its engagements with mental health professionals, students, parents, governments, survivors and media. Rahi aims to create an environment where child sexual abuse and incest are prevented and responded to through appropriate policies and practices.

To help Rainbow Trust Children's Charity raise its profile and increase the number of families it cares for in northeast London and Essex in England. Rainbow Trust Children's Charity is the leading charity in England, providing expert social palliative care to families who have a child with a life threatening or terminal illness. It supports around 2,000 families a year.

To prevent violence against children at schools, home and communities in Uganda. Raising Voices has focused on creating a National Dialogue to engage Ugandans in a conversation about VAC. Concurrently it has developed an evidence based methodology for preventing Violence Against Children at school (Good School Toolkit). This project aims to integrate the two strands into a consolidated strategy that begins at school and moves in concentric circles around the school to create a comprehensive community based intervention at scale.

To improve how small scale fisheries are represented to and financed by the international community. This will increase the environmental and social resilience of coastal communities and reduce the loss of biodiversity that underpins coastal ecosystems and the productive economy.
To support Reden International so that it can keep its night cafeÌ

To provide core support to RMC, which supports asylum seekers, migrants and refugees in Wolverhampton and Birmingham. RMC delivers free advice and support services, primarily to newly arrived and destitute asylum seekers, refugees and EU migrants.

To reduce destitution and homelessness in Glasgow among asylum seekers. This will be done by: providing a multi-agency, integrated support service with increased capacity to offer advocacy, safe accommodation and legal support; and advocating for wider changes to the asylum system in Scotland. The Refugee Survival Trust provides a range of services and support to asylum seekers and refugees living in Scotland.

To provide core support to RHLS, a not-for-profit organisation based in Pennsylvania (United States). It helps create sustainable communities that offer good-quality, safe and affordable housing for lower-income people.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To identify innovative policy solutions that will increase and protect Pennsylvania's supply of affordable housing. RHLS will focus on issues such as foreclosure, repair of affordable multi-family homes and public housing reform. RHLS is a non-profit law firm with expertise in affordable housing, community and economic development and utility matters.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To explore and research the issue of high rates of eviction in Philadelphia, the US, with a view to improving policy so that levels of evictions are reduced. The Reinvestment Fund works across several states in the US to finance development that benefits low-income communities.

To support Relay Graduate School of Education to develop and pilot the Special Education Leadership Academy fellowship, which will prepare special educators to lead schools in supporting the academic and social-emotional success of students with learning differences. Relay works to train teachers and school leaders to develop in all students the academic skills and strength of character needed to succeed in college and life.

Organisation: Research Foundation of the City University of New York
Purpose: To create alternatives to New York City Housing Authority's permanent exclusion practices for residents who have been involved with the criminal justice system. The Prisoner Re-entry Institute at John Jay College of Criminal Justice seeks to spur innovation and improve practice in the field of re-entry by: advancing knowledge; translating research into effective policy and service delivery; and fostering effective partnerships between criminal justice and non-criminal justice disciplines.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To build knowledge of and enable positive public discourse on human rights in the UK. Based in London, Rights Info will produce and disseminate engaging, accessible and well-presented online human rights content. The aim is to improve knowledge about human rights in an engaging, informative and entertaining way.

To counter abusive practices and policies that violate fundamental rights, in particular in relation to the measures taken by states in pursuit of national security and in conflict. Rights Watch UK will engage in research, strategic litigation and advocacy, and will organise wider campaigns to mobilise the public.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To increase the amount of affordable and supportive housing units in New York City owned and managed by not-for-profit developers. The Fund will achieve this by providing loans to pre-approved borrowers for them to quickly secure housing sites. Robin Hood is a foundation fighting poverty in New York City.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To improve the lives of New Yorkers in poverty and bring down barriers to opportunities that block them. Robin Hood Foundation achieves this by finding, funding and partnering with organisations that help New Yorkers in need, including children, families and young adults as well as immigrants and veterans.

To launch climate mitigation efforts by identifying and supporting innovative leaders with transformative strategies. The Climate Breakthrough Project is an initiative of the David and Lucile Packard Foundation in partnership with Oak Foundation and Good Energies Foundation.

To rapidly escalate the availability of philanthropic funding through a funders' collaborative to organisations that can work strategically and internationally to meet and challenge the plastics crisis. The aim is to eliminate all non-essential use of plastics by 2035.

To support Oceans Five - an international funders collaborative - which supports projects to constrain overfishing and establish marine reserves. The collaborative is highly opportunistic, sharing its collective resources, staff and experience to support a portfolio of common projects.

To support the Sustainable Development Goals Philanthropy Platform (SDGPP) in India. The aim of this platform is to assist donors to create thoughtful and effective philanthropic practices based on partnerships and collaboration. The enhanced networking will accelerate efforts to sustain the goals as per the SDG 2030 agenda.

To create and support a group of Chinese cities to achieve goals of peaking CO2 emission in advance of the 2030 national goal, with some before 2022. This project will focus on supporting the government-sponsored Alliance of Pioneer Peaking Cities (APPC) initiative. The APPC will provide the tools, practices and exchange mechanisms to advance urban low-carbon solutions and ensure that at least the existing 23 cities and provinces participating in the initiative are on a pathway to peak emissions early.

To prevent violence against children by empowering fathers and other male caregivers in Bulgaria. This will be done by actively encouraging male caregivers involvement in children's lives. This project will build on a previous Men Care campaign that took place in the country. Eight Bulgarian non-governmental organisations will support the implementation of this campaign.
Sub Programme: Engaging men and boys in ending sexual abuse

Organisation: Royal Foundation of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry
Purpose: To increase rhinoceros populations in priority sites in Southern Africa, and to support the effective disruption of trafficking of wildlife products through engagement with the transport sector.

To support the construction of a state-of-the-art research and clinical care centre at the Royal Marsden Hospital in Sutton, the United Kingdom. This will help treat an increased number of adult cancer patients and speed up research and clinical progress. The Royal Marsden Hospital is the largest comprehensive cancer centre in Europe.

To support the Royal Marsden Hospital in London, the United Kingdom, to develop new treatments for children and teenagers with cancer to improve the survival and reduce the long-term health effects of cancer treatments. This will be achieved through research (in particular drug development) and clinical trials.

To research the impact of recent changes in commissioning and service delivery in the UK homelessness and related social justice fields. Russell Webster Limited is an independent consultancy with expertise in public sector research and evaluation.

To provide core support to RJI to protect and assist the victims of human rights violations related to armed conflicts and counter-terrorism operations, as well as torture and gender-based violence in post-Soviet regions. RJI engages in domestic and international litigation and builds the capacity of legal professionals through training, legal consultations, mutually beneficial partnerships and original research and publications on relevant human rights topics in our region.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Organisation: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
Purpose: To conduct an evaluation of the Moving On initiative in New York City. Rutgers University will work with project partners to use the findings to influence good practice in future schemes that facilitate moving on from supportive housing. Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, is a leading national research university.

To provide core support to Safe Horizon’s Street work Project in New York. Safe Horizon works to provide support, prevent violence and promote justice for victims of crime and abuse, as well as for their families and communities. A cornerstone of this mission is the Street work Project, which seeks to empower homeless young people in New York City through: comprehensive, trauma-informed services; the development of innovative, replicable programme models to meet their needs; and systems-level advocacy to increase awareness and supportive resources for vulnerable youth.

To provide SafeLives with core support to end domestic abuse in the UK. This will be delivered through the provision of practical tools, training, guidance, quality assurance, policy advice and data to professionals and organisations working with domestic abuse victims.

To create technology that provides high-resolution, full-depth mapping of the oceans sea floor. Saildrone will collaborate with the Central Caribbean Marine Institute (CCMI), the UK’s National Oceanography Center (NOC) and the US's National Oceanic and Administrative Administration (NOAA).They will plan the first autonomous mapping mission of the Cayman Trough, a complex fault zone on the floor of the western Caribbean Sea between Jamaica and the Cayman Islands.

To support SAMVAD to strengthen community life and empower traditional governance systems in the villages of minority peoples in India. SAMVAD is a not-for-profit organisation established in 2001 in the state of Jharkhand working to promote self-rule and governance, natural resource management, sustainable livelihoods and indigenous culture.

To promote enabling workplaces for women in India that are free from sexual harassment. This will also help improve livelihood opportunities for women. Sanhita aims to carry out this work in the state of West Bengal, and on a smaller scale in Jharkhand.

To advocate, promote and implement comprehensive sexuality education for children and adolescents in Switzerland. Through this grant, SSCH aims to prevent sexual violence against children and to increase the involvement of men and boys in the promotion of gender equality and the prevention of sexual violence. SSCH works to promote sexual and reproductive health in Switzerland, notably through family planning and sexual education.
Sub Programme: Engaging men and boys in ending sexual abuse

Organisation: Sarstoon Temash Institute for Indigenous Management
Purpose: To build the institutional self-reliance and capacity of Sarstoon Temash Institute for Indigenous Management (SATIIM) so that it continues to function as a national and global leader in environmental and human right defence and sustainable development. SATIIM is a community-based indigenous peoples environmental and human right organisation that works in southern Belize.

To tackle the link between social disadvantage and fewer life chances for children in poor areas of the UK. Informed by innovative models in the US, SCUK has designed a new model for the UK which brings existing services together under an overarching strategy that addresses the needs of children from birth to young adulthood. This model will be piloted in four communities and results will be monitored to build an evidence base for replication.

Organisation: Save the Children India - Bal Raksha Bharat
Purpose: To strengthen the Integrated Child Protection Scheme in order to reach children and families by training and placing a cohort of Community Cadres at the Panchayat level in selected districts of Jharkhand and West Bengal.

To prevent and tackle online child sexual abuse and exploitation by supporting the governments and communities in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The project will also strengthen the legal and judicial systems to prevent and prosecute online sexual abuse and exploitation of children.
Sub Programme: Ending the sexual exploitation of children

Organisation: School of International and Public Affairs (Columbia University)
Purpose: To conduct a pilot capacity-building programme to strengthen the international human rights movement. The programme, which will involve an initial cohort of up to 16 grantees, will be designed, executed and evaluated by a senior research scholar at the University's School of International and Public Affairs.

To increase access to affordable credit by establishing Scotcash, a community lending service, in Edinburgh. Scotcash is an independent, social enterprise that provides affordable credit and additional services that address the needs of lowest income households in Glasgow and beyond.

To develop peer mentoring support in Bristol, the United Kingdom, in order to reduce and prevent homelessness and to enable people with histories of homelessness to lead more independent, fulfilling lives. Second Step provides housing and support services to people with: mental health issues; a history of homelessness; complex needs, including substance misuse and offending; and learning difficulties.

To accelerate the uptake of electric vehicles in the US and create an enabling policy environment for driverless cars. SAFE unites military and business leaders to advocate for policies that improve Americas energy security by curtailing dependence on oil and promoting responsible use of domestic energy resources.

To support the implementation of off-grid solar solutions by building an eco-system for affordable finance that is available to the poor in Jharkhand, India. Off-grid solar is fast becoming the most viable solution to provide productive electricity to some of the remotest and most underserved families of Jharkhand. SELCO Foundation has been doing pioneering work to address these barriers.

To create and protect ownership and economic opportunity among single-headed households in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. The Women's Homebuyer Initiative helps households break out of economic hardship by making homeownership more affordable.

To support India's goal of making 100 per cent of its transportation electric by 2030. This will be achieved by supporting the manufacturing of electric vehicles, developing standards, and demonstrating the success of electric vehicles in urban areas. Shakti Sustainable Energy Foundation works to facilitate India's transition to a cleaner energy future by aiding the design and implementation of policies that promote clean power, energy efficiency, sustainable transport, climate policy and clean energy finance.

To support energy conservation and efficiency in India, with a focus on policy design and stakeholder capacity building for timely policy implementation. Shakti Sustainable Energy Foundation works to facilitate India's transition to a sustainable energy future by promoting policies that encourage energy efficiency, renewable energy and sustainable transport solutions.

To facilitate India's transition to a sustainable energy future by promoting policies that encourage energy efficiency and an increased uptake of renewable energy sources. Shakti Sustainable Energy Foundation works to facilitate India's transition to a sustainable energy future by encouraging energy efficiency and the increased generation of renewable energy.

To assist India in adopting a clean energy, low carbon development pathway. This project will promote investment in green infrastructure and inform climate mitigation policies through the provision of greenhouse gas emissions data and policy discourse.

To prevent people in Wales from becoming homeless. This will be done through several initiatives, including a project to keep in contact with people over several years, to learn from their housing journeys. An accredited training programme will be developed for those who have been homeless, to help them gain skills and employment. Shelter Cymru provides housing and legal advice in Wales and campaigns to prevent homelessness.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To provide core support for Shobana Jeyasingh Dance to continue producing and touring dance works across the United Kingdom and internationally. This grant will also provide opportunities to share Shobanas creative vision through a high-quality learning and participation programme for underserved communities.

Organisation: Sidney De Haan Research Centre for Arts and Health
Purpose: To provide core support to the Sidney De Haan Centre for Arts and Health in the UK. The Centre intends to research how participating in performing arts activities, including singing, is beneficial for wellbeing and health. The Centre aims to encourage commissioners of health and social care services to support creative and musical activities for older people with chronic long-term illnesses such as Parkinson's disease and dementia.

To enable Sifa Fireside, a key organisation working in Birmingham's homelessness sector, to become more sustainable, by implementing a strategic business plan to enhance and expand its training function. SIFA Fireside works to improve health and inclusion for homeless people.

To develop a multi-agency team with a shared vision and approach to support rough sleepers in Glasgow to engage with services. The Simon Community is a long-established provider of services to homeless people in Glasgow focusing on prevention of rough sleeping, intensive outreach, emergency access, supported accommodation and life skills development.

To raise awareness among children, youth and households about healthcare and economics to improve their health and psychological wellbeing. Simukai also seeks to enable access to education and training for children and youth. Simukai aims to reach 1,700 vulnerable children, 300 youth and1,500 households.
Sub Programme: Women, children and elderly at risk

Purpose: The general aim of the project is to give people in Greenland, that live with mental illnesses, and their relatives, access to information about mental illnesses. SIND has the capacity to administrate this project. The organisation already possess the information material in Danish. To adjust the material to societal relations in Greenland, SIND is collaborating with SUGISAQ. The role of SUGISAQ will be to adjust the material to Greenland through relevant cases, and distribute the information pamphlets.
To provide education, skills training, shelter, warmth, food and financial assistance to adults with intellectual disabilities at Sir Humphrey Gibbs Training Centre.

To work with human rights organisations and courts to present evidence more persuasively and effectively through the application of spatial analysis and visualisation. Based in New York City, SITU Research is an arm of an architectural practice that seeks to broaden the toolkit of investigative techniques available to human rights investigations.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To significantly reduce CO2 and air pollutants from road freight in China. In addition this grant will help achieve broader economic and social benefits by catalysing the sector-wide adoption of proven, cost-effective technologies and measures. The Smart Freight Centre aims to make the global freight sector more efficient and environmentally sustainable.
To increase and improve efforts at responding to and preventing violence against children by supporting the integration of the â€œResilience Approachâ€
To pilot an adaptive, nonconventional approach to security for organisations operating in the wildlife conservation sector.

To enable Social Good Funds project Fearless Collective to elevate the presence of people (primarily women) who have been historically misrepresented and denied access to public spaces and social movements. Using public art and participative storytelling, Fearless seeks to create and reclaim spaces with these communities. Fearless is a growing global network of young artists and activists.

To influence policy makers in the UK to implement changes to the benefit sanctions system. These changes should minimise the potential negative impacts on those who are sanctioned and provide protection for more vulnerable claimants, while also ensuring that employment is improved. The Social Market Foundation is an independent, non-partisan think-tank which works to promote sensible, fair and evidence-based public policy.

To support women and girl victims of sexual violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo by providing medical and psycho-social aid and legal and economic support. SOFEPADI will also advocate with communities and the judiciary to change attitudes and promote women's ability to access and exercise their right to lives free of violence.

To strengthen violence prevention work with men and boys in Uganda and Tanzania, Sonke will partner with Promundo to disseminate the findings of the International Men and Gender Survey (IMAGES). Sonke will also work with partner organisations in Tanzania and Uganda to produce reports on the state of fatherhood in each country. These reports will inform programming and policy implementation aimed at promoting the positive engagement of men and boys to prevent violence against children.
Sub Programme: Engaging men and boys in ending sexual abuse

Purpose: To ensure that children and youth in Latvia grow up in a caring family environment either with biological or professional foster parents. SOS Children's Villages aims to improve quality and access to family support for children and their families in order to prevent child abuse and neglect and to reduce the risks of social exclusion.

Organisation: SOS CORPO Instituto Feminista para a Democracia
Purpose: To provide core support to the mission of SOS CORPO in Recife, Brazil to promote women's rights and gender equality. This grant will also contribute to building a just, democratic and equitable society. With this grant, it aims to strengthen women's movements locally, nationally, regionally and internationally to support the implementation of public policies that will help overcome socio-economic inequalities. This grant includes support for the creation of the Pernambuco women's Movement Support Fund that will be re-granted by SOS CORPO to strengthen local grassroots groups.

To fight impunity for gross human rights violation in Africa and worldwide through strategic litigation. Based in Johannesburg, the Southern Africa Litigation Centre is a not-for-profit organisation that promotes human rights and the rule of law through litigation support and training.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To enable the grantees of the Learning Differences and Prevent Child Sexual Abuse Programmes to participate in the executive coaching programme led by Spitfire Strategies. Spitfire Strategies is a communications firm that provides strategic communications solutions and support to not-for-profit groups.

The purpose is to re-establish a ski lift in Qaqortoq in the southern part of Greenland. The project is a result of the energy that was created with the Murmal project which was supported by Oak Foundation Denmark. The ski lift can bring people in the town together both in establishing it and later as a social meeting place for all generations.

To enable StART to continue its work to develop community-led housing at the St Anns Hospital site in Haringey, North London. StART was established by a group of local residents and workers who want to put local people in control by: developing affordable homes; promoting health and wellbeing; and creating a “green neighbourhood".
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Organisation: St Katharine's the Danish Church in London
Purpose: To support the renovation of the Danish Church in London, which is the only Danish church in London. For many Danes it is also a meeting place away from home where they participate in social, cultural and religious events. The Church is also used for Danish language classes for Danish children and adults.

To support research at the Statens Serum Institutin Denmark. This grant aims to prevent and treat pregnancy complications and childhood diseases by investigating environmental and genetic influences on health during pregnancy and early childhood. The Statens Serum Institut is a government institution under the Danish Ministry of Health. It is one of Denmarks largest research institutions and is responsible for the Danish preparedness against infectious diseases, biological threats and control congenital disorders.

To provide core support to Stop It Now! to prevent the sexual abuse of children by mobilising adults, families and communities in the United States to take actions that protect children before they are harmed. Stop it Now! provides online and print resources, tools and programme strategies that help parents, professionals and community leaders create safe, nurturing environments for children.
Sub Programme: Engaging men and boys in ending sexual abuse

Purpose: To provide a full continuum of services for economically disadvantaged students in Durham Public Schools in North Carolina - beginning in sixth grade - to successfully graduate from high school and college.

Organisation: Supportive Housing Network of New York
Purpose: To provide core support to the Supportive Housing Network of New York, a membership organisation representing over 200 supportive housing providers across New York State. Together they provide more than 50,000 units of supportive housing.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Organisation: Supportive Housing Network of New York
Purpose: To reduce the time taken to develop supportive housing; and reduce costs, by conducting data-driven analyses of systemic barriers to the development of supportive housing; and taking action to reduce them. In addition, SHNNY will work to reduce the impact of community opposition and advocate for increased funding for supportive housing. It will develop replicable tools that can be adopted across New York and other states.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To enable Surviving Economic Abuse (SEA), based in the UK, to expand its work of raising awareness about economic abuse. The outcome of SEA`s work will ensure that the general public have an understanding of economic abuse and service providers are able to help victims and survivors. SEAs vision is a world in which women and girls achieve economic equality and are able to live their lives free of abuse and exploitation.

To provide core support to Partners for a New Economy (P4NE), an international donors collaborative fund supported by the Swiss Philanthropy Foundation.P4NE works to generate and employ new partnerships and systems-level interventions to transform how our environment and economy are valued.

To provide core support to Swisscleantech to conduct business advocacy in Switzerland focused on sustainable development. Through this grant, Swisscleantech will become a broadly supported organisation and a strong voice for the sustainable economy in Switzerland.

Support to establish Sydhavnen Resource hus: A new and including user and volunteer house. The effort will strengthen the opportunities of the target group and ensure continuous personal wins, as tasks and activities are tailored to the individual and organized accordingly. The effort will also strengthen the target group's ability to form lasting relationships and be an alternative to a daily life.

To provide core support to the Tactical Technology Collective to advance the skills, tools and techniques of human rights activists. Based in Berlin, it supports human rights defenders both remotely and directly to protect their privacy, safeguard their security, use information and technology more effectively for social change, and expand their digital toolboxes.
Sub Programme: Supporting and protecting human rights defenders

Purpose: To provide materials to the dental clinic Tandrødderne in Copenhagen.

The main aim of the project is to give the network surrounding a family where there is domestic violence some tools to intervene as soon as they become aware of the violence. The project is for the network around a family affected by domestic violence such as neighbours, various kinds of social workers, work colleagues, janitors in building complexes, schools, parents in kindergartens - anyone who can do something to help stop the violence.

To increase domestic climate philanthropy and support for organisations working on climate change mitigation in India. This will be achieved by establishing a climate-focused donor advisory and philanthropic coordination platform for Indian philanthropies. Tata Trusts plays a pioneering role in transforming traditional ideas of charity and introducing the concept of philanthropy to make areal difference to communities.

To provide core support to Teach For All to increase and expand educational opportunities for disadvantaged students around the world. Teach For All is helping a network of partners shape a generation of global leaders to drive innovative, broad-scale, systemic change to ensure that all children have the opportunity to attain an excellent education.

To support Teach for America to strengthen training and support of teachers in the Eastern North Carolina region. This will help meet the needs of diverse learners and build more equitable classrooms.

To support Teach For America to incorporate an orientation around learner variability and disability justice into its programme continuum to reach 3,500 new teachers each year. This will start with the integration of Universal Design for Learning into its national pre-service programme. Teach For America will also create an ecosystem of learning that connects its 53 regions and over 46,500 alumni to collaborate around best practices that will lead to expanded opportunities for all children, including those with learning differences.

To support Terre des Femmes to provide comprehensive and culturally sensitive counselling services and assistance specifically designed for migrant women who are victims of domestic violence living in Bern, Switzerland. Terre des Femmes Switzerland works to prevent human rights violations against women and girls.

Organisation: Terre des hommes Foundation "Lausanne" in Hungary
Purpose: To strengthen systems and professional competencies to protect children's fundamental rights to be protected from abuse across South East Europe. This will be done by further developing and expanding the scope of the Child Protection Hub for South East Europe (ChildHub - childhub.org) - an online resource centre that provides technical assistance, knowledge and research to support policy and practice.

To provide support to the Children Win Campaign, which promotes child rights in the bidding processes of sporting organisers, and to the Destination Unknown Campaign, which works to protect children on the move. TDH works to defend and promote the rights of children.

To prevent child abuse and improve the safety and wellbeing of children, particularly those living in rural communities in Moldova. Through this project, Terre des hommes Moldova plans to prevent violence among school children by transforming school culture, empowering children and equipping teachers with necessary knowledge and skills. It will increase parental capacities and tackle harmful social norms that permit violence against children.

To promote human rights and social justice in Myanmar through grant-making and capacity-building support to grassroots organisations. Tharthi Myay Foundation (TMF) has three programme areas: Human Rights and Legal Education; Gender Rights; and Inclusive Education (with a cross-cutting focus on individual rights). TMF assists local groups across the country to build collaborative platforms and strong networks to advocate for change at the national and regional levels.
Sub Programme: Supporting and protecting human rights defenders

Purpose: To support the African Wildlife Foundation’s project in the Savé Valley Conservancy in Zimbabwe, where it works to protect wildlife, including a critical population of rhinos. The conservancy seeks to improve its rhino protection programme and to facilitate the translocation of rhinos, in the long-term, to populate other areas. The project will provide critical salary and equipment support for rangers; enhance the existing intelligence gathering network; and allow for biological monitoring of the rhino population and maintenance of natural habitat.

To help protect elephant populations in Mana Pools National Park and the Lower Zambezi Valley in Zimbabwe, Africa by strengthening ranger capacity, supporting park management, investing in core infrastructure and establishing robust monitoring systems. The project addresses the threats that poaching operations pose to the park and surrounding landscape, thereby helping ensure the viability of one of Africa's most important elephant populations.

Organisation: The Andrei Sakharov Foundation -Commission for Academic Sakharov Heritage Preservation
Purpose: To provide core support to the Sakharov centre to promote Sakharovs values and memory and support its traditional activities, including public debate. This builds on existing efforts to target a younger generation through human rights education, photography and theatre. In addition it supports a new initiative to mobilise that same cohort into public service via volunteering.

Organisation: The Carlos Acosta International Dance Foundation
Purpose: To establish an international dance school in Cuba for underprivileged gifted and talented dancers from across the globe. The Carlos Acosta International Dance Foundation has a vision to create a world-renowned centre of excellence to give training and education to young dancers who would otherwise not have the opportunity.

To continue to build the capacity of grassroots organisations to plan, manage and implement programmes that increase access to healthy foods and connect limited-resource farmers with community markets to strengthen and build more inclusive local food systems. The Conservation Funds Resourceful Communities programme aims to increase food security so that community members can access, grow and distribute safe, affordable and local healthy food.

Organisation: The Dr. Robert C. Cantu Concussion Center at Emerson Hospital
Purpose: To help launch the Dr. Robert Cantu Concussion Center to conduct research in the science of concussion management, return to play and inter-professional treatment protocols. The Center will also provide community education, timely health assessments, evidence-based recovery recommendations and treatment.

To consolidate the organisational development of the Engine Room and expand its support to human rights activists to integrate data and technology safely and effectively into their work. Based in locations around the world, the Engine Room also conducts applied research on the role of technology in advocacy, producing research and tools on the use of data by non-governmental organisations.
Sub Programme: Supporting and protecting human rights defenders

Purpose: To support the Foundling Museum in London to train young adults who grew up in institutional care to develop and deliver creative workshops at the Museum for children in care. Both the trainees and children will benefit from the project and will learn new skills and feel empowered. The Foundling Museum explores the history of the Foundling Hospital, the UK's first children's charity and first public art gallery. Through a dynamic programme of exhibitions and events, the Museum celebrates the ways in which artists of all disciplines have helped improve children's lives for over 275 years.

Organisation: The Guernica Centre for International Justice
Purpose: To support transnational and international accountability strategies to tackle impunity in nine countries. The Guernica Centre for International Justice, part of the Guernica Group with offices in the UK, US and Spain, is an international collaboration of experienced litigators, investigators and other professionals working together to bring perpetrators of international crimes and grave human rights violations to justice and strengthen systems of accountability.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To strengthen the leadership capacities of Oaks partners by facilitating access to quality coaching services. The Kairos Project works to increase the impact of charities and not-for-profit organisations worldwide. It does this by empowering senior management teams through executive coaching and leadership development.

Organisation: The Massachusetts Association of Community Development Corporations (MACDC)
Purpose: To promote joint health and housing initiatives and increase the supply of affordable housing in local suburban communities throughout Massachusetts. MACDC is a membership organisation of individual community development corporations. It focuses on developing affordable housing, local small businesses and other programmes that have a focus on reducing poverty and promoting social cohesion.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To support innovative grassroots women's organisations that lead movements for transformative change to: dismantle barriers, change systems, challenge perceptions and transform society. MATCH is an international women's fund based in Canada. It works to mobilise resources and provide funding to grassroots women's organisations in the Global South. It aims to strengthen their capacity, support connecting and networking, and build relationships.
To provide Mediterranean Women's Fund (MWF) with core support, enabling it to help build strong national and regional women's movements.

To facilitate accountability, truth seeking, preservation of accurate historical memory and reconciliation in the North Caucasus. The project will secure the safekeeping and presentation of records of historical and legal value, including through a public website that mirrors information kept in the confidential online database and promoting it through independent media and social networks.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Organisation: The Public Health Foundation of Georgia (PHF)
Purpose: To strengthen the child abuse prevention and response capacity of the primary health care system in Georgia and Azerbaijan. The project will increase doctors knowledge and skills to identify and respond to child abuse cases, including sexual abuse. It aims to increase the understanding of healthcare professionals around multi disciplinary collaboration. In addition, through this project, the Public Health Foundation of Georgia plans to strengthen its organisational capacities to be more sustainable.

To support low-income families in Philadelphia to live and thrive in safe, healthy and affordable homes. Low-income tenants, particularly African Americans, Latinos and women, will strengthen their ability to advocate for themselves and to reform and influence government policies and court procedures. The Public Interest Law Center uses high-impact legal strategies to advance the civil, social, and economic rights of communities in the Philadelphia region facing discrimination, inequality, and poverty.

To support the Queen's Commonwealth Trust in its work to provide small grants to young people throughout the Commonwealth, to help them get good ideas off the ground. Young entrepreneurs in developing countries often have the best ideas for solving local problems, but they lack access to development funding. The Queen's Commonwealth Trust will work through partners to identify these projects and get start-up funds to them quickly; it will also provide mentoring and networking opportunities to help elevate good ideas and share best practice for replication elsewhere.

To develop a homeless health programme to support community nurses based in the UK to develop knowledge, skills, resources and services to improve care for people who are homeless or vulnerably housed. The QNI is dedicated to improving care for patients and their families and carers in the home and community, by increasing the provision, quality and effectiveness of community nursing services.

Organisation: The Regents of the University of California
Purpose: To support the Human Rights Center at UC Berkeley School of Law to conduct research on war crimes and other serious violations of international law in order to improve conditions for survivors and prevent future violence. Using scientific methods and innovative technologies, it will support efforts to hold perpetrators accountable and protect vulnerable populations. It will also train students and advocates to document human rights violations and turn this information into effective action.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To build the capacity of a group of Oak Foundation grantees through a programme of assessment, training, strategy development, coaching and mentoring. The Alliance works with not-for-profit organisations around the world to help them achieve financial sustainability by building skills and knowledge and by promoting excellence within society.

To recruit a Development Coordinator to increase the Rock Trusts capacity to provide services in more parts of Scotland and to develop new initiatives. The Rock Trust serves vulnerable and homeless young people by helping them build the personal capacity to have a healthy and independent adult life.
To identify and nurture outstanding young professional singers, conductors, reÌ

To provide core support and to further the development of the Sacconi quartet, its annual festival and associated charitable activities. The Sacconi Quartet performs regularly at London's major venues and across Europe.

To support the Sixteen, a choir and period-instrument orchestra committed to preserving and championing its choral heritage, to prepare for its 40th anniversary year in 2019.The Sixteens touring, recording and education programme aims to reach as wide and diverse an audience as possible. It also aims to break ground with new commissions and partnerships, to create a global following without boundaries and to nurture the next generation of musicians.

To support the Story of Stuff Project to partner with a small group of organisations in North America, Europe and Asia to align the plastic pollution movement and to build its power. The Story of Stuff is a community of more than a million changemakers worldwide, working to build a healthier and more just planet.

To support Sutton Trust's UK summer school programme and an expansion of the programme into Wales. UK summer schools aim to improve social mobility across the UK by enabling highly-able young people from under-privileged backgrounds to access top higher education opportunities. The programme dispels some of the myths that prevent young people from applying to leading universities and from accessing top career paths, breaking the link between birth and educational opportunity.

To support the Value Web's Global Commons project, which aims to establish new norms to operate within planetary boundaries. This will be achieved by developing science-based targets fora range of environmental challenges for business, investors and governments to operate within the boundaries of our planets resources.

To support the UK-based 'The Syria Campaign' in its work to elevate Syrias heroes and build global support behind them. The Syria Campaign works remotely to create a bridge between those trapped inside Syria facing violence on all sides and the international community. Believing in freedom, democracy and peace, it works to raise awareness of civil society groups in media and popular culture. By doing so it hopes to encourage the sense that there is a Syria worth protecting. This will also help ensure that the peoples voices are heard in political discussions on Syria's future.

To provide core support to the TWC, an organisation based in North Carolina, the US, that provides resources to educators to engage students physically, mentally and academically. With TWC materials, students take brisk 20-minute walks while listening to podcasts that are aligned with the common core standards for 4th and 5th grades. Students establish and maintain healthy lifestyle habits while building their health literacy and core content knowledge as they walk, listen and learn.

To prepare the Welcome Organisation in Belfast, Northern Ireland, to identify, develop and implement a succession strategy to prepare for the director's retirement. The Welcome Organisation delivers services to homeless and vulnerable people in Belfast. It supports people to gain the skills they need to find housing, achieve economic stability, overcome barriers to work and sustain employment.

To fund 25 fellows in the United Kingdom annually to travel 6-8 weeks around the world with the aim of exploring new ways of tackling various challenges currently facing the UK. The hope is that these fellows will bring back new knowledge and best practice that will positively impact their professions and communities in the United Kingdom.

To enable exceptionally talented young musicians, regardless of race, creed or financial background, to attend a specialised music and academic programme at the Yehudi Menuhin School in the United Kingdom. The programme will train them to become professional musicians. The school, now recognised as a world-class institution, has been providing education for exceptionally gifted young string players, pianists and classical guitarists for the last 50 years.

Organisation: The Young Center for Immigrant Children's Rights
Purpose: To enable the Young Center for Immigrant Children's Rights to inform US decision-makers on the reality of life in the home countries of unaccompanied child migrants who face the risk of being repatriated to dangerous situations.

To increase civil society capacity and enhance international diplomatic capacity to support the transition to clean power. This will be achieved by building a diplomatic network that encourages strong climate leadership. E3G is an independent climate change think tank working to accelerate the global transition to a low-carbon economy.

To support Thorn in its continued development, roll-out and maintenance of a technological tool called 'Solis', which fights child sexual exploitation on the dark web. The tool is used by law enforcement officers worldwide to find and rescue victims and to identify and prosecute perpetrators who use the dark web to try to evade the law.

To advance a new approach to oceans governance in British Columbia that integrates and fosters environmental, social and economic wellbeing and resilience. The Marine Plan Partnership aims to serve as a global model for collaborative oceans governance with indigenous communities. Tides Canada Foundation works to support Canadians to secure a healthy environment in ways that promote social equity and economic prosperity.

To support the Code Blue Campaign that seeks to end impunity for sexual abuse by UN peacekeeping personnel. This includes removing barriers to justice for victims, and establishing a fair and transparent system of justice where victims needs are incorporated and respected. Tides Center works to accelerate the pace of social change by working with innovative partners to solve society's toughest problems.
Sub Programme: Ending the sexual exploitation of children

Purpose: To help implement the UN Guidelines for the Alternative Care of Children and childcare related policies and practices at global, regional and country levels. This will be done by developing and testing new approaches and promoting practice-based learning and sharing. Better Care Network (BCN) is an international network of organisations committed to supporting children without adequate family care around the world. BCN is the fiscal sponsor for this grant.

To create a continuum of sustainable and effective services for all Chapel Hill and Carrboro youth. For example, a website and mobile phone application will assist youth and parents in connecting to services. Youth Forward is a project of Tides Centre and works to increase human and organisational capacity building for not-for-profit organisations serving youth.

To build relationships between people living in mobile homes (also known as manufactured homeowners) in the US, who number more than 9 million mainly low-income people in approximately 50,000 land-lease sites. The aim is to help enact policy change that supports all manufactured homeowners. Manufactured housing is a significant but unrecognised form of low-income housing and many of those living in this type of housing have limited rights and representation. Manufactured Housing Action is a growing national movement of manufactured homeowners who work to protect the affordability and quality of their communities through national, state and local campaigns.

To administer grants out of the Children First Fund to support the planning and implementation of strategies to protect children against violence around the world. Tides Foundation is a San Francisco-based not-for-profit organisation that makes grants to charitable organisations. Created by Prevent Child Sexual Abuse Programme (Prevent CSAP) in 2014, the Children First Fund supports Prevent CSAP’s partners to improve planning, deliver policy inputs and increase the evidence base of violence against children.

To improve wildlife crime law in German-speaking European countries and to establish a global hub for legal expertise around protecting wildlife. TIR works to improve and protect animals through legal, ethical and social means.
To establish a pangolin rehabilitation programme. The Tikki Hywood Foundation strives to bring awareness and sound conservation practice to the plight of lesser known and endangered animals globally.

To increase understanding of boys' experiences of violence, including sexual abuse, and to strengthen their inclusion in global and country-level policy and programmes. Together for Girls is a global partnership dedicated to ending violence against children, with a focus on sexual violence against girls.
Sub Programme: Engaging men and boys in ending sexual abuse

Purpose: To use the power of information and storytelling to exchange the story on sexual violence against children and adolescents. Using data as its guide, TfG aims to: raise awareness; build local capacity; promote evidence-based solutions; and galvanise coordinated action across sectors and stakeholders to ensure that girls and boys can live free from violence.

To strengthen women’s civil society organisations, groups and movements working to end violence against women in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia and Montenegro. Trag will manage grant-making and reporting for grantees that are building movements and addressing intimate partner violence, trafficking and exploitation in the Issues Affecting Women Programmes Balkans portfolio. Trag will also provide grantees with strong tailor-made capacity building, mentoring and accompaniment.

To conduct a study to strengthen potential supply chains in Jharkhand so that small-scale farmers, forest-dependent communities and other small-scale producers can enhance their incomes and their access to the viable markets. Following the study, Traidcraft Exchange UK will be able to propose alternative, fairer and more inclusive supply chain models that can be tested and upscaled.

To prevent sexual violence against children at national and local levels in Uganda. At the national level, TPO will support the National Child Protection Working Group to continue convening stakeholders to share experiences and lessons. At the local level, TPO will support communities in the Lira district to implement elements of the INSPIRE package to prevent sexual violence against children.

To provide support to Transcend to design and build school models that help all children in the US learn in supportive, engaging and effective learning environments. Transcend partners with education leaders to co-create new school model designs and ensure that all aspects of the process respond to diverse learner profiles. Transcend enables visionary learning communities to build and spread breakthrough models that prepare all children to thrive in and transform the 21st century.

To challenge the impunity of individuals and corporate actors involved in gross human rights violations and secure redress for the victims of these crimes. Based in Switzerland, TRIAL International investigates serious international crimes, brings strategic litigation on behalf of victims and raises public awareness on issues of impunity.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To expand the National Youth Forum on Homelessness, create a network of influential Youth Advisory Boards across the US, and provide the resources to support them to end youth homelessness. True Colors provides advocacy, training, education and youth collaboration programmes in the US, working to ensure that no young person is homeless due to their sexual orientation or gender identity.

To improve the quality, stability and affordability of private sector housing for low-income households in London. It will also strengthen the voice of tenants in the sector to become more actively involved in advocacy work to bring about improvements. Trust for London is an independent charitable trust that exists to tackle poverty and inequality in London.
Sub Programme: Increasing the supply of low-income housing

Purpose: To build a strong anti-impunity movement across Africa by strengthening the capacity of civil society organisations to contribute to transitional justice policy at national level. This grant will also help develop informed and coordinated advocacy strategies to promote international criminal justice at regional and international levels. Through its donor collaborative, the International Criminal Justice Fund, TrustAfrica will develop strategies and build the capacity of organisations working against impunity in Africa.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To prevent the negative effects of poverty on the welfare, safety and educational development of children in communities in Bulgaria. This will be done by empowering parents, families and communities to protect their children from neglect, violence, abuse, insufficient care and unnecessary placement in institutions. Work with men and boys will be interwoven into all project activities. Tulip Foundation works to reduce the abandonment and institutionalisation of children.

To expand the Turn2us helpline to prevent and reduce homelessness, poverty and destitution by providing specialist, targeted and timely information and guidance. Turn2us will also analyse data and findings to inform policy work to improve services for those in financial hardship. Turn2us is a leading charity working to alleviate poverty in the UK.

To address local housing and homelessness issues in specific regions of the UK by providing grassroots organisations with development grants to build sustainability, develop ideas and deploy innovative solutions. UK Community Foundations is the umbrella organisation for community foundations across the UK who will deliver this project.

Organisation: UNI Global Union, The World Players Association
Purpose: To carry out a survey of professional athletes about how their rights were promoted or violated as children in organised sport. The World Players Association brings together 85,000 players across professional sport through more than 100 player associations in over 60 countries.

Organisation: UNI Global Union, The World Players Association
Purpose: To support the coordination of the Sports and Rights Alliance (SRA), a coalition of leading global organisations which are working together on human rights, labour rights, children's rights, anti-corruption and sustainability in sport.
Sub Programme: Ending the sexual exploitation of children

Purpose: To mitigate the risk of violence to youth aged 15-24 in Tanzanian households. The project will examine the potential for cash plus interventions to facilitate safe, healthy and productive transitions to adulthood. This will be built within the governments existing cash transfer programme, enabling the inclusion and empowerment of youth.
Sub Programme: Ending the sexual exploitation of children

Organisation: UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund
Purpose: To prevent and respond to online child sexual abuse and exploitation through targeted and evidence-based programmes at national, regional and global levels. The grant aims to support work to reduce online violence, expand knowledge of online safety among individuals and society, establish industry standards, and strengthen systems to investigate and prosecute online violence, as well as support survivors.

To raise the profile of children's participation at European level in challenging and preventing sexual violence. The project will also fund an Oak Fellow (based at the University) to provide support to the University and Oak Foundation.
Sub Programme: Ending the sexual exploitation of children

Purpose: To further protect Belizes marine protected areas by implementing strategies that link them to livelihoods and by building the resilience of the ecosystem. The university will develop its scientific capacity to identify and address the impacts of climate change. It will establish a programme that educates young Belizeans on the importance of climate resilience and adaptation.

To document and communicate the annual trends of the world’s marine fisheries catches via an online platform. Through this project, Sea Around Us will document the catch of small-scale fisheries and will communicate the findings to the conservation community and to policy makers.

To provide leadership to the Faculties of Environmental Design and the Haskayne School of Business at the University of Calgary. This will be done through the Richard Parker Professorship in Metropolitan Growth Management and Change. Through enhanced collaboration between development, urban design and planning, this programme works to create cities that are healthier, more resilient and liveable.

To support the Human Rights Center at UC Berkeley School of Law to conduct research on war crimes and other serious violations of international law in order to improve conditions for survivors and prevent future violence. Using scientific methods and innovative technologies, it will support efforts to hold perpetrators accountable and protect vulnerable populations. It will also train students and advocates to document human rights violations and turn this information into effective action.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To support the University of California San Francisco's brainLENS laboratory in assessing the impact of a mentoring programme on the socio-emotional, resilience and academic outcomes of young people with learning differences. It will then identify profiles of young people most likely to benefit from mentoring. This grant will also support the international dissemination of research results and free resources that will aid mentoring programmes in deepening their impact on young people who learn differently.

Organisation: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Purpose: To develop an inpatient and outpatient programme to serve teenage burn survivors. The North Carolina Jaycee Burn Center at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will launch a pilot programme dedicated to meeting the complex health needs of teenagers for successful re-entry and adjustment into society after suffering a severe burn injury. The goal is to create a model other burn centres could use to serve teen populations.

To support the development of new therapeutic approaches for multiple sclerosis (MS), at the University of Oxford, in the United Kingdom. The project will integrate and analyse a vast amount of information from MS patients to understand better the biological mechanisms responsible for the disease progression and to develop new treatments.

To contribute to the next generation of researchers in the field of infectious diseases by supporting four outstanding scientists in the early stages of their careers in Nepal, Vietnam, Zimbabwe and Kenya. These scientists will be connected to overseas units affiliated to the University of Oxford.

Organisation: University of Washington Center for Game Science
Purpose: To modify and test an internationally available technology platform to provide teachers with proven strategies and interventions in math. The platform will allow teachers to deploy real-time, in-class individualised support to ensure every student achieves key learning milestones. The University of Washington Center for Game Science will develop the technology and partner with the not-for-profit organisation Enlearn to pilot and test existing products.

Organisation: University Settlement Society of New York, Inc
Purpose: To expand University Settlements proactive eviction prevention model for public housing tenants and to institutionalise the approach on a broader scale in New York City Housing Authority. University Settlement is a leading settlement house located in the Lower East Side of Manhattan in New York City serving 30,000 low-income individuals annually.

To support the Karolinska Institute in Sweden to develop and test a scalable, non-stigmatising and low-cost clinical intervention for refugees and survivors of rape across Europe suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. This intervention will be drawn from advanced psychological research on mental health and will be delivered through an app.

Organisation: Urgent Action Fund for Women's Human Rights
Purpose: To provide core support to the Consortium of Urgent Action Funds in their efforts to strengthen the resilience and impact of women's movements around the world. This will be done by: providing rapid response grant-making to improve the security and wellbeing of women human rights defenders (WHRD); strengthening the capacity of women's rights organisations; increasing leadership, capacity, and knowledge of WHRD; and laying the groundwork for the creation of a new Urgent Action Fund for the Asia Pacific region.

Organisation: US Committee for Refugees and Immigrants
Purpose: To ensure the long-term safety and stability of unaccompanied children in North Carolina by offering legal assistance and mental health services. The US Committee for Refugees and Immigrants protects the rights and addresses the needs of persons in forced or voluntary migration worldwide. It does this by: advancing fair and humane public policy; facilitating and providing direct professional services; and promoting the full participation of migrants in community life.

To expand the Soccer for Success programme with the goal of impacting the lives of one million youth each year by 2026. U.S. Soccer Foundation seeks to ensure that all children grow and thrive in community environments where safe spaces to play, positive mentors, and engaging out-of-school programmes are the norm. U.S. Soccer Foundation recognises the sports powerful potential to improve the health and wellbeing of youth throughout the United States.

To further V&A Dundee's mission to enrich lives through design, by supporting the new museums programme for children and young people (aged 16 - 24). The museum opened in mid-September 2018: an international centre of design presenting the brilliance of Scottish creativity and the best of design from around the world. Support of the learning programmes ensures design continues to inspire, spark and fire young imaginations.

The purpose of this application is to secure financial support for running Vesterbro Maduddeling and further developing it so that it changes from a street-level project to a n organization with management, a steering committee and a clear structure.

To document and expose human rights violations and other systemic abuses in some of the worlds most oppressive and violent regimes. Videre builds sustainable activist networks, gives them the equipment and training necessary to document abuses safely and effectively, and shares this footage with key stakeholders that can effect change.
Sub Programme: Ending impunity for gross human rights violations

Purpose: To extend and deepen grassroots arts engagement across the UK and the Republic of Ireland so that participation in creative cultural activity for at least two hours per week becomes recognised as the norm. The hope is that creative cultural activities become widely adopted as a key component of a healthy lifestyle for older people, contributing especially to mental wellbeing.

To support the consolidation of Memria, a social enterprise that enables human rights and social justice organisations to collect, analyse and distribute personal narratives. Memria works with partners to help them better engage the public, mobilise their constituencies and use stories to construct powerful narratives to realise human rights.

To help a new generation of combat veterans successfully reintegrate into society. Through the experience of fly fishing in Montana, Warriors &Quiet Waters is a catalyst for positive change in the lives of post-9/11combat veterans.

To provide core support to the WAVE Network to provide advice, research, mobilisation and capacity building support to women's organisations in 46 European countries, that provide services to women and children who are experiencing gender based violence. WAVE is a formal network of European women's non-governmental organisations that are working towards ending violence against women and children across Europe.

Organisation: We are Not the Machine Ltd
Purpose: To support a documentary feature film. This documentary explores the themes of coming out and acceptance of gay people in Kenyan society.

To support the Wessex Chalk Stream and Rivers Trust to protect and improve the chalk streams and rivers of the Wessex region in southern England. Wessex harbours nearly 25 per cent of the worlds chalk streams. Specialist staff and dedicated volunteers collaborate on research, education, habitat restoration and catchment management to ensure the health and survival of this unique and rare ecosystem.

To support WIDE+ to build feminist movements in Europe in response to current political, social and economic developments. WIDE+ strives for rights-based societies in which all people have the power to control assets and resources, to influence decisions affecting their lives and livelihoods, to decide over their own bodies and lives and develop their full potential.

To engage and empower stakeholders in the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef in efforts to reverse the decline in threatened marine wildlife, notably sharks and rays. MarAlliance implements positive change for threatened marine wildlife, their habitats and dependent human communities. MarAlliance works with WCN, its fiscal sponsor to achieve its objectives.

To support Alaska Natives in articulating their needs relating to sustainable marine mammal hunting - the cornerstone of the food and economic security of Arctic indigenous communities. WCS works with local partners to help conserve the world's largest wild places, home to more than 50 percent of the world's biodiversity.

To strengthen civil society and government partnerships to combat rhino horn trafficking networks between Africa and China. WCS's goal is to conserve the world's largest wild places in 16 priority regions, home to more than 50 per cent of the world's biodiversity.

To establish a sanctuary for elephants and rhinos orphaned in the wild or in need of care at the Hoedspruit Endangered Species Centre. Also, to develop a synthetic formula for elephant milk. The Wildlife Conservation Trust (WCT) oversees projects with a focus on conservation, rehabilitation and protection of wildlife. It also implements education and training programmes relating to the environment.
To analyse, map and understand the networks allowing for trade in rhino horn and ivory in Asia in a bid to improve conservation efforts.

To provide core support to Wildlife SOS, an organization founded in 1995 to protect and conserve India's natural heritage, forest and wildlife. Wildlife SOS is also involved in conserving habitat, studying biodiversity, conducting research, rescuing wildlife and creating alternative and sustainable livelihoods for poacher communities and those communities that depend on wildlife for sustenance.

To seek the absolute prohibition of torture in Russia through: independent investigation of torture cases, domestic and international litigation; advocacy and public campaigns to mobilise supporters and educate the broader public about torture; and public monitoring mechanisms.
Sub Programme: Freedom from arbitrary detention and torture

Purpose: To support the implementation of WITNESS' new expanded strategy over the next 18 months and assist in its regionalisation process. For more than two decades, WITNESS has made an impact by combining cutting-edge innovation with unique expertise in human rights to build the capacity of activists to expose abuses through the safe and effective use of video.
Sub Programme: Supporting and protecting human rights defenders

Purpose: To support women in the United Kingdom who are experiencing domestic abuse and are homeless to re-integrate into their communities, and to support WAITS to become sustainable. WAITS works to ensure women get their voices heard and to provide opportunities for all women.

To enable WAA to develop, implement and embed a new Economic Empowerment Project aimed at reducing homelessness and increasing long-term economic stability for women and children who experience domestic abuse. WAA is the leading domestic abuse advocate and service provider in Philadelphia. Its services include housing, legal services, counselling, community education and advocacy programmes.

To increase the participation, leadership and influence of frontline/grassroots women leaders on issues that impact women and their communities. This will be done by: strengthening their communication skills; making their knowledge and expertise visible; enabling them to bring their messages to a wider audience; and building a movement of senior decision makers globally that work to implement their recommendations.

To provide core support to Women Deliver, a global advocate for gender equality and the health, rights and wellbeing of girls and women. Women Deliver brings together diverse voices to drive progress for all, including on maternal, sexual and reproductive health and rights. Women Deliver builds capacity, shares solutions and forges partnerships to create coalitions and catalyse actions that spark political commitment and investment in girls and women.

Organisation: Women in Dialogue (for Women Against Rape - WAR)
Purpose: To provide core support to WAR, enabling it to empower victims to be better informed, stronger and more confident advocates. WAR also works to improve access to justice for survivors of rape and domestic violence and supports women who have fled to the UK to escape rape or domestic violence.

To support Win-Win Strategies to connect the power of business with women’s funds and organisations to economically empower women globally. Win-Win Strategies works with and for women’s funds, women’s local organisations and companies to create meaningful partnerships and practical business initiatives for women.

To provide support to domestic abuse services in the United Kingdom so that they become more sustainable and their organisational and financial stability are increased. Women's Aid Federation of England is a UK-based organisation which supports women and children who have suffered from, or are exposed to, gender-based violence.

To provide core support to WFG, enabling it to advance its mission of empowering women and the women's movement in Georgia. This will be done by providing financial and technical support, capacity building and developing feminist philanthropy. The grant will also contribute to the organisational development of WFG, a local grant-making organisation that supports women's groups, activities and initiatives for social change in Georgia.

Organisation: Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF)
Purpose: To provide core support to WILPF to strengthen the capacity of frontline women's organisations to mobilise for peace, equality, justice and human security. In doing so, women's organisations will influence laws and policies to better protect women and their communities from violent conflict. WILPF is an international not-for-profit anti-war organisation that brings women together to oppose conflict, violence and global militarisation.

To provide core support to WLC to continue its work to ensure the protection of women's rights and help reduce violence against women in Moldova. WLC supports a human-rights based approach and strives for change at individual, community and systemic levels. It focuses on: policy advocacy, monitoring implementation of new laws and protection mechanisms; and providing legal services to women and children affected by domestic violence.

To provide core support to continue using the power of law to promote social change that advances the human rights of women and girls. Women’s Link takes the law beyond the courtroom by: strengthening the human rights infrastructure; shaping public debates; and contributing to social movements that transform society and guarantee women’s and girls rights. Women’s Link uses legal, communications and mobilisation strategies to work across three themes: reproductive rights, violence and discrimination.

To ensure that every migrant in the US, particularly women, children and families, have full access to legal protection and safety as provided by the Refugee Convention and international human rights standards. WRC's Migrant Rights and Justice Program monitors immigration detention facilities' conditions, undertakes advocacy based on policy and legal reviews and research into Alternatives to Detention, and provides technical assistance to federal agencies and community organisations.
Sub Programme: Freedom from arbitrary detention and torture

Purpose: To improve the prevention and response efforts of humanitarian actors working to reduce sexual violence against boys and men, including gay, bisexual, and transgendered persons. The aim is to help reduce sexual violence in crisis-affected communities, including against women and girls.
To support local implementing partners in Zimbabwe to provide 4500 cataract and 300 burn reconstructive surgeries to adults and children across the country over a three year period.

To provide core support to Working Chance to expand its service delivery into the North of England and to develop its care leavers service. Working Chance is the UK's only specialist recruitment consultancy for women with criminal convictions and women care leavers. It supports women into employment placements and develops relationships with potential employers, including larger private sector corporate partners.

To maintain and grow an online social network connecting women worldwide so they can create positive change in their communities and thrive. World Pulse harnesses the power of technology to unite women - both online and off - to be heard, to share resources, launch movements, start businesses, run for office, or courageously tell their story.

To strengthen WRIs global network by expanding the capacity and resilience of its international offices in Brazil, China and India. The World Resources Institute is a global research organisation that was established in1982.

To protect Arctic coastal and ocean ecosystems and the Indigenous peoples and wildlife that rely on them by empowering Indigenous rights holders.
