This will be done by: implementing a network of marine protected areas to protect critical habitats; developing regulations that constrain the cumulative impacts of shipping within sustainable limits; and establishing small-scale fishing opportunities that support sustainable livelihoods.

To support the establishment and operationalisation of the Global Climate Action Initiative, which promotes the implementation of the Paris Agreement and green development, especially in developing countries. WWF International works to tackle the drivers of environmental problems.

To ensure the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) will finance renewable energy projects exclusively in Vietnam, Myanmar and the Philippines. Promoting and accelerating a transition to renewables along the BRI, especially in Southeast Asian countries, will positively impact global efforts to combat climate change and will help create a clean, healthy and sustainable future for local people.

To assist and accelerate Chinas economic transition towards a low-carbon development path and to guide the â€˜One Belt, One Road Initiative in a green and sustainable direction. The aim of the â€˜One Belt, One Road Initiative is to promote the orderly and free flow of economic factors by enhancing the connectivity of Asia, Europe and Africa. This project will help China and the â€˜One Belt, One Road countries achieve their climate change commitments. The project also seeks to facilitate the phasing-out of ivory trade in China.

To address the challenge of global fisheries sustainability by increasing collaborative actions in China. WWF has registered a fundraising entity in China that will help build an industrial fishing portfolio in China in the coming years.

To eliminate illegal fishing in the Korean fishing industry and instead promote transparent, sustainable fisheries. This will be done by: engaging with Korean fishing and tuna industry actors in discussions; providing awareness-building opportunities to distant water fleet owners; and working with distant water fleet owners to encourage voluntary transparency/traceability practices.

To provide young people with an opportunity to engage in the conservation of the environment through internship programmes in WWF's offices around the world and to develop the world's future leaders in sustainable development. WWF works to conserve nature and reduce the most pressing threats to the diversity of life on Earth.

To provide core support to x:talk to enable it to continue mobilising and empowering sex workers in the UK and globally to improve their working lives. This grant will also support sex workers to challenge the laws and stigma that place them at risk of violence and exploitation. X:talk is a grassroots sex worker-led cooperative that provides peer support services to migrant sex workers. It is active in the struggle for sex workers and migrant workers in the UK and globally.

To adapt the YouthBuild schools diploma granting model to Mexico, Brazil and South Africa, where pathways to secondary education credentials for early high-school leavers are currently not available. This school model will be responsive to diverse learning needs. It will provide experiential learning environments and opportunities to build leadership among a global network of youth across multiple countries, who have a shared experience of disconnection, dislocation and marginalisation.

To provide core support to Z2K to develop its services in London. Z2K seeks to support people on low incomes who face debt due to housing and household expenditure or who are in dispute with the welfare benefit system. It also lobbies for improvements to the legal and benefits system in the UK and provides training to volunteers and community groups on issues of debt management and welfare reform.

To provide core support to Zimcare Trust. Zimcare works to facilitate an enabling environment for learning and care programmes that are anchored in individual needs and designed to help each person to excel.

To create a “refill revolution" across the city of London by 2021, which will reduce the number of single-use plastic water bottles entering the ocean. This will be done by creating a culture in the city where using and refilling are fillable water bottle is accepted as the social norm.

To realise the potential for growth of both black rhino and elephant populations in the Tsavo Conservation Area in Kenya. This will be done by: developing the rhino programme together with Kenyan Wildlife Services (KWS); securing Tsavos elephant population by providing intelligence on threats; and providing anti-poaching support to KWS by developing rapid-response teams and improved proactive law enforcement in target areas.
